channel.title: seafood – Chow Down Orlando
channel.description: Exploring all that Orlando has to offer.

item.title: Dixieland Diner
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
This is the pecan crusted catfish served on a bed of sweet potato cheese grits from the Dixieland Diner food truck. While the picture is very orange, the food was delicious. The breading on the fish was very light but crispy and the sweet potato in the cheese grits were a very nice touch. You […]

The post Dixieland Diner appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
This is the pecan crusted catfish served on a bed of sweet potato cheese grits from the Dixieland Diner food truck. While the picture is very orange, the food was delicious. The breading on the fish was very light but crispy and the sweet potato in the cheese grits were a very nice touch.

You can find Dixieland Diner on Twitter.

The post Dixieland Diner appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: City Fish
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
City Fish is in the heart of downtown. It’s a great, laid back seafood place that cranks out great food. It’s a place that we enjoy going to when we’re in the mood for quality seafood at decent prices. Pictured at the top was the chef’s special of the evening in almond crusted corvina. I […]

The post City Fish appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
City Fish is in the heart of downtown. It’s a great, laid back seafood place that cranks out great food. It’s a place that we enjoy going to when we’re in the mood for quality seafood at decent prices.

Pictured at the top was the chef’s special of the evening in almond crusted corvina. I had never heard of the corvina fish, but was told it is a flakey white fish similar in style to mahi. I was sold. Man was it good.

Also pictured is the macaroni and cheese and fried pickles that also graced the table, both of which are delicious.

At the bottom is the fried Oreo dessert. If you haven’t tried a fried Oreo, you don’t really know what you’re missing and at City Fish they do it right by throwing them in a bed of ice cream. It’s a great way to close out the meal.

City Fish is found on Central near the corner of Summerlin downtown.

The post City Fish appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: Monster Lobsta
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
This is actually the second time I’ve eaten at Monsta Lobsta and both times I went with the standard lobster roll. The roll is 4 oz of lobster meat mixed with a bunch of delicious filler. Some people with us were surprised the roll was cold, but I don’t think being cold takes anything away […]

The post Monster Lobsta appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
This is actually the second time I’ve eaten at Monsta Lobsta and both times I went with the standard lobster roll. The roll is 4 oz of lobster meat mixed with a bunch of delicious filler. Some people with us were surprised the roll was cold, but I don’t think being cold takes anything away from the flavor. The bun is toasted and very good.

The total package is very good and, despite being the most expensive truck I’ve eaten at, is well worth the cost. Not pictured, Carla tried the lobster lasagna which was a special. Based on her report, she wouldn’t let me have any, it was delicious.

You can find Monsta Lobsta on Twitter.

The post Monster Lobsta appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: High Tide Harry’s
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
Before High Tide Harry’s opened at it’s new location a year or so ago it was basically a dive bar that sold quality seafood. When the new location opened, basically doubling the size, the same dive bar feel was kept, just elevated to a grand scale. Note that this is very a good thing. High […]

The post High Tide Harry’s appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
Before High Tide Harry’s opened at it’s new location a year or so ago it was basically a dive bar that sold quality seafood. When the new location opened, basically doubling the size, the same dive bar feel was kept, just elevated to a grand scale. Note that this is very a good thing.

High Tide Harry’s sells seafood in mass quantities. To say their menu is large is a gross understatement. Huge. Massive. Those words are closer to the truth. And this doesn’t even include the special menu that’s covers the doors as you walk in.

Pictured are the Mahai Bites special that I shared with my brother. We got one order blackened which was very well seasoned and another order fried. As my brother put it, the fried bites could have been any type of white fish and we wouldn’t have known. This is true, but they were good none the less. Also pictured are the mini scallops that Carla ordered, which were just slightly overcooked but still very good, her fishbowl drink, and the High Tide Harry’s Hush Puppies. These are basically balls of fried cornmeal but are served with a wonderful cinnamon butter that I put on just about everything served.

When I say the food comes in massive quantities, I’m not kidding. The Mihai Bites special was $9.99 and included ½ pound of fish and two side items. In my case a baked potato and green beans. I call that a good bang for your buck.

Overall the food is pretty good, especially if you’re very hungry.

High Tide Harry’s is loaded on 436 near the airport.

The post High Tide Harry’s appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
